article.h1: Ammonia observations of the nearby molecular cloud MBM 12

div.p: We present NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}(1,1) and (2,2) observations of MBM 12, the closest known molecular cloud (65 pc distance), aimed to find evidence for on-going star formation processes. No local temperature (with a Trotsubscriptùëárotitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start rot POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{\rm rot} upper limit of 12 K) nor linewidth enhancement is found, which suggests that the area of the cloud we mapped (‚àº15‚Ä≤similar-toabsentsuperscript15‚Ä≤RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:15 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 15^{\prime} size) is not currently forming stars. Therefore, this close ‚Äústarless‚Äù molecular gas region is an ideal laboratory to study the physical conditions preceding new star formation.

A radio continuum source was found in Very Large Array archive data, close but outside the NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†emission. This source is likely to be a background object.

article.div: keywords: ISM: Clouds ‚Äì ISM: Individual objects: MBM 12 ‚Äì Radio lines: ISM

div.p: MBM 12 (Magnani, Blitz, & Mundy 1985) is the closest known molecular cloud. Its distance has been estimated to be ‚àº65similar-toabsent65RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:65\sim 65 pc (Hobbs, Blitz, & Magnani 1986). This means that the distance to MBM 12 is less than half of that to the closest star-formation complexes (e.g., 140 pc to Taurus). Therefore, determining the presence of star-forming processes in MBM 12 would allow us to get deep into the smallest possible physical scales of these processes. For instance, for young low-mass stars a critical scale is ‚àº100similar-toabsent100RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:100\sim 100 AU, which is the estimated size of protoplanetary discs, and the distance at which jets are being collimated [Rodr√≠guez 1989]. A size of 100 AU at 65 pc will extend ‚àº1.‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Å¢5similar-toabsentsuperscriptitalic-.fragments‚Ä≤‚Ä≤15RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:5\sim 1\aas@@fstack{\prime\prime}5, which is a resolution attainable at present, for instance by millimetre interferometers already operating. However, similar studies in more distant star-forming regions would require sub-arcsecond resolution, for which we will have to wait until the next generation of interferometers is available.

Although no ongoing star-formation has been detected so far within this high-latitude cloud, the presence of T Tauri stars [Pound 1996] outside, but close to the bulk of the CO emission (Pound, Bania, & Wilson 1990; Zimmerman & Ungerechts 1990; Moriarty-Schieven, Andersson, & Wanner 1997), suggests that, at least in the near past, this cloud has been a star-forming site. However, it might be possible that these T Tauri stars are run-away objects from other star-forming regions. The detection of embedded young stellar objects would then be the only way to confirm whether MBM 12 is actually a star-forming region.

Reach et al.¬†[Reach et al.¬†1995] have determined the presence of dense gas (‚â≥104greater-than-or-similar-toabsentsuperscript104RELOP:greater-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\ga 10^{4} cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}, traced by CS emission) in some areas of MBM 12, forming clumps in near virial equilibrium (i.e., dynamically bound, not just density fluctuations in a turbulent medium). Therefore, these are possible pre-stellar cores (Ward-Thompson et al.¬†1994) that merit further study.

In this paper, we present single-dish NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†observations aimed to search for evidence of on-going star formation in MBM 12. NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†observations can be used to identify the presence of current star formation processes. The ratio between different NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†transitions give us temperature information (Ho & Townes 1983). Local heating effects traced by ammonia have been successfully used to locate young stellar objects (e.g., G√≥mez et al.¬†1994; Girart et al.¬†1997). Moreover, local peaks of linewidth could indicate local turbulence enhancements, which are also very likely associated with star-forming processes.

We also used radio-continuum observations from the Very Large Array (VLA) of NRAO111The National Radio Astronomy Observatory is a facility of the National Science Foundation operated under cooperative agreement by Associated Universities, Inc. archive, to look for possible embedded young stellar objects.

Observations of the NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}(1,1) and (2,2) inversion lines (rest frequencies ŒΩ11=23.6944955subscriptùúà1123.6944955italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:23.6944955\nu_{11}=23.6944955 GHz, and ŒΩ22=23.7226333subscriptùúà2223.7226333italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:22 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:23.7226333\nu_{22}=23.7226333 GHz) were taken with the 37m antenna at Haystack Observatory222Radio Astronomy at MIT Haystack Observatory is supported by the US National Science Foundation. on 1998 March 17-24, and 1998 May 13-15. The beam size of the telescope at this frequency is ‚àº1.‚Ä≤‚Å¢44similar-toabsentsuperscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤144RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:44\sim 1\aas@@fstack{\prime}44 (which corresponds to ‚àº0.03similar-toabsent0.03RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.03\sim 0.03 pc on MBM 12). We used a dual maser, cryogenically cooled receiver, which was tuned at a frequency midway between those of the observed lines, and with VLSR=-5.0subscriptùëâLSR5.0italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LSR POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5.0V_{\rm LSR}=-5.0 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. The autocorrelation spectrometer was configured to measure a bandwidth of 53.3 MHz with 1024 lags, which gave a spectral resolution of 62.85 kHz (0.8 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}). This system setup allowed us to obtain spectra that included both NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†lines. Two circular polarizations were also obtained simultaneously. The rms pointing error was estimated to be ‚àº11‚Ä≤‚Ä≤similar-toabsentsuperscript11‚Ä≤‚Ä≤RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:11 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 11^{\prime\prime}, with observations of Saturn. The reference position of our NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†maps is Œ±‚Å¢(1950)=02h‚Å¢53m‚Å¢08.s‚Å¢9ùõº1950superscript02‚Ñésuperscript53ùëösuperscriptitalic-.ùë†089italic-alpha OPEN:( NUMBER:1950 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:02 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:53 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:08 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. italic-s POSTFIX:end NUMBER:9\alpha(1950)=02^{h}53^{m}08\aas@@fstack{s}9, Œ¥‚Å¢(1950)=+19‚àò‚Å¢14‚Ä≤‚Å¢15‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùõø1950superscript19superscript14‚Ä≤superscript15‚Ä≤‚Ä≤italic-delta OPEN:( NUMBER:1950 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:19 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:14 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:15 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\delta(1950)=+19^{\circ}14^{\prime}15^{\prime\prime}. The spectra have all been corrected for antenna gain and atmospheric attenuation. Typical system temperatures are ‚àº100similar-toabsent100RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:100\sim 100 K. The final spectra have been smoothed up to a velocity resolution of 1 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, yielding an rms noise level of ‚àº0.03similar-toabsent0.03RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.03\sim 0.03 K. Data reduction was performed with the program CLASS of IRAM and Observatoire de Grenoble.

We also used archive VLA data towards this region. These data correspond to B-array, 3.6 cm continuum observations, originally taken by D. Helfand and J. Halpern on 1990 Aug 2, to search for a radio counterpart of the X-ray pulsar H0253+193 (see Patterson & Halpern 1990; Zuckerman et al.¬†1992). An effective bandwidth of 100 MHz, and two circular polarizations were observed. The phase centre was located at Œ±‚Å¢(1950)=02h‚Å¢53m‚Å¢20.s‚Å¢5ùõº1950superscript02‚Ñésuperscript53ùëösuperscriptitalic-.ùë†205italic-alpha OPEN:( NUMBER:1950 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:02 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:53 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:20 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. italic-s POSTFIX:end NUMBER:5\alpha(1950)=02^{h}53^{m}20\aas@@fstack{s}5, Œ¥‚Å¢(1950)=+19‚àò‚Å¢14‚Ä≤‚Å¢38‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùõø1950superscript19superscript14‚Ä≤superscript38‚Ä≤‚Ä≤italic-delta OPEN:( NUMBER:1950 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:19 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:14 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:38 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\delta(1950)=+19^{\circ}14^{\prime}38^{\prime\prime}. The source 1328+307 was used as the primary flux calibrator, with an assumed flux density of 5.19 Jy. The phase calibrator was 0235+164, for which a flux density of 3.44¬±0.06plus-or-minus3.440.06NUMBER:3.44 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.063.44\pm 0.06 was derived. Calibration and further image processing was performed with the program AIPS of NRAO. The resulting synthesized beam was 0.‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Å¢84√ó0.‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Å¢72superscriptitalic-.fragments‚Ä≤‚Ä≤084superscriptitalic-.fragments‚Ä≤‚Ä≤072NUMBER:0 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:84 MULOP:times NUMBER:0 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:720\aas@@fstack{\prime\prime}84\times 0\aas@@fstack{\prime\prime}72, and the rms noise level 1.0√ó10-21.0superscript102NUMBER:1.0 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1.0\times 10^{-2} mJy beam-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}.

Figure 1 shows the emission of the NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}(1,1) line detected at different velocities. Figure 2 shows the integrated intensity map. Several clumps of ammonia emission are evident in this latter figure, the most intense one centred around position offset (1.‚Ä≤‚Å¢44,0.‚Ä≤‚Å¢00)superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤144superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤000OPEN:( NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:44 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:00 CLOSE:)(1\aas@@fstack{\prime}44,0\aas@@fstack{\prime}00). The observed clumps tend to align forming two clear filamentary structures, one extending south to north between position offsets (1.‚Ä≤‚Å¢44,-2.‚Ä≤‚Å¢88)superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤144superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤288OPEN:( NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:44 PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:88 CLOSE:)(1\aas@@fstack{\prime}44,-2\aas@@fstack{\prime}88) and (1.‚Ä≤‚Å¢44,4.‚Ä≤‚Å¢32)superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤144superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤432OPEN:( NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:44 PUNCT:, NUMBER:4 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:32 CLOSE:)(1\aas@@fstack{\prime}44,4\aas@@fstack{\prime}32), and the other one from southeast to northwest between (-2.‚Ä≤‚Å¢88,1.‚Ä≤‚Å¢44)superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤288superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤144OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:88 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:44 CLOSE:)(-2\aas@@fstack{\prime}88,1\aas@@fstack{\prime}44) and (7.‚Ä≤‚Å¢20,4.‚Ä≤‚Å¢32)superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤720superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤432OPEN:( NUMBER:7 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:20 PUNCT:, NUMBER:4 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:32 CLOSE:)(7\aas@@fstack{\prime}20,4\aas@@fstack{\prime}32). The morphology seen with our NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†maps is similar to the one in CO (Pound et al.¬†1990; Zimmerman & Ungerechts 1990; Moriarty-Schieven et al. 1997), and specially to the CS map [Reach et al.¬†1995]. Figure 3 shows an averaged spectrum within a box of 3‚Ä≤√ó3‚Ä≤superscript3‚Ä≤superscript3‚Ä≤NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end3^{\prime}\times 3^{\prime} around (1.‚Ä≤‚Å¢44,0.‚Ä≤‚Å¢00)superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤144superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤000OPEN:( NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:44 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:00 CLOSE:)(1\aas@@fstack{\prime}44,0\aas@@fstack{\prime}00), which includes the NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†emission from the most intense clump. Apart from the central, main hyperfine component, the satellite lines of NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}(1,1) are also evident. No NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}(2,2) line emission was detected in our spectra. This emission is not present even in the average within the 3‚Ä≤√ó3‚Ä≤superscript3‚Ä≤superscript3‚Ä≤NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end3^{\prime}\times 3^{\prime} box around (1.‚Ä≤‚Å¢44,0.‚Ä≤‚Å¢00)superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤144superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤000OPEN:( NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:44 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:00 CLOSE:)(1\aas@@fstack{\prime}44,0\aas@@fstack{\prime}00), with an upper limit333Upper limits and errors are given in this paper for a 99% confidence level. of 0.0200.020NUMBER:0.0200.020 K.

img.figcaption: Figure 1: Contour maps of NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}(1,1) intensity, at different velocities. The LSR velocity (in km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}) is indicated at the bottom left corner of each panel. The lowest contour is 0.09 K and the increment step is 0.03 K (1‚Å¢œÉ1ùúéNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma). The filled circle indicates the position of the radio source VLA B0253+192. Crosses indicate the observed points. The beam size is indicated as a circle at the bottom right corner.

Figure 2: Contour map of the integrated emission of the NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}(1,1) main hyperfine component. The integration range was between -8.18.1ADDOP:minus NUMBER:8.1-8.1 and -2.92.9ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.9-2.9 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. The lowest contour map is 0.15 K km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and the increment step 0.05 K km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. Symbols have the same meaning as in Fig.¬†1.

Figure 3: Averaged spectrum of the NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}(1,1) line, within a box of 3‚Ä≤√ó3‚Ä≤superscript3‚Ä≤superscript3‚Ä≤NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end3^{\prime}\times 3^{\prime} around position offset (1.‚Ä≤‚Å¢44,0.‚Ä≤‚Å¢00)superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤144superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤000OPEN:( NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:44 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:00 CLOSE:)(1\aas@@fstack{\prime}44,0\aas@@fstack{\prime}00).

div.p: No radio continuum emission is detected within the bounds of the ammonia emission, with an upper limit to the flux density of 2.3√ó10-22.3superscript102NUMBER:2.3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end2.3\times 10^{-2} mJy. Only an unresolved source is present within the primary beam of the VLA, with a flux density of 0.114¬±0.026plus-or-minus0.1140.026NUMBER:0.114 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.0260.114\pm 0.026 mJy, at position Œ±‚Å¢(1950)=02h‚Å¢53m‚Å¢26.s‚Å¢38ùõº1950superscript02‚Ñésuperscript53ùëösuperscriptitalic-.ùë†2638italic-alpha OPEN:( NUMBER:1950 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:02 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:53 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:26 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. italic-s POSTFIX:end NUMBER:38\alpha(1950)=02^{h}53^{m}26\aas@@fstack{s}38, Œ¥‚Å¢(1950)=+19‚àò‚Å¢14‚Ä≤‚Å¢44.‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Å¢4ùõø1950superscript19superscript14‚Ä≤superscriptitalic-.fragments‚Ä≤‚Ä≤444italic-delta OPEN:( NUMBER:1950 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:19 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:14 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:44 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:4\delta(1950)=+19^{\circ}14^{\prime}44\aas@@fstack{\prime\prime}4 (we name this object as VLA B0253+192). Note that the phase centre of the VLA observations is located at position offset (2.‚Ä≤superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end\aas@@fstack{\prime}74,0.‚Ä≤superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end\aas@@fstack{\prime}38) in our NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†maps, and the primary beam at 3.6 cm is 5.‚Ä≤‚Å¢4superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤54NUMBER:5 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:45\aas@@fstack{\prime}4 (FWHM). Therefore, this primary beam includes the whole central clump. The position of VLA B0253+192 is indicated in Figures 1 and 2.

The main goal of our NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†observations was to identify the presence of on-going star formation processes, by measuring local temperature and turbulence enhancements.

In our data, the lack of NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}(2,2) emission indicates a low temperature throughout the mapped area. In particular, from the averaged data for the most intense clump, around (1.‚Ä≤‚Å¢44,0.‚Ä≤‚Å¢00)superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤144superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤000OPEN:( NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:44 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:00 CLOSE:)(1\aas@@fstack{\prime}44,0\aas@@fstack{\prime}00) (see Fig.¬†3), and using the values for the main and inner satellite components TA‚Å¢(1,1;m)=0.117subscriptùëáùê¥11ùëö0.117italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:; italic-m CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.117T_{A}(1,1;m)=0.117 K ¬±0.022plus-or-minus0.022ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.022\pm 0.022 K, TA‚Å¢(1,1;i‚Å¢s)=0.041subscriptùëáùê¥11ùëñùë†0.041italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:; italic-i italic-s CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.041T_{A}(1,1;is)=0.041 K ¬±0.016plus-or-minus0.016ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.016\pm 0.016 K, TA‚Å¢(2,2;m)<0.020subscriptùëáùê¥22ùëö0.020italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:; italic-m CLOSE:) RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.020T_{A}(2,2;m)<0.020 K, we derive an optical depth of œÑ‚Å¢(1,1;m)=0.69ùúè11ùëö0.69italic-tau OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:; italic-m CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.69\tau(1,1;m)=0.69 and an upper limit to the rotational temperature of ‚àº12similar-toabsent12RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:12\sim 12 K. This temperature is similar to those found in other high-latitude clouds, including MBM 7 [Turner 1995], which is close to MBM 12. It is also expected for this rotational temperature to be close to the value of the local kinetical temperature [Turner 1995]. No local linewidth enhancement is seen in our data. Typical linewidths seem to be unresolved with our 1 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}¬†velocity resolution.

From these results we conclude that no indication of current star formation is evident in our NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†data. This suggests that T Tauri stars seen close to MBM¬†12 [Pound et al.¬†1990] were formed in a near past, but star-forming processes are no longer going on, at least in the area we mapped. Alternatively, those T Tauri stars may be runaway objects from nearby star-formation sites.

However, Reach et al. [Reach et al.¬†1995] estimated that MBM 12 is a potential star-forming cloud, given the similar mass derived from the CS integrated intensity and the virial mass. In our data, for the main clump around (1.‚Ä≤‚Å¢44,0.‚Ä≤‚Å¢00)superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤144superscriptitalic-.‚Ä≤000OPEN:( NUMBER:1 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:44 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:italic-SUPERSCRIPTOP italic-. SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:end NUMBER:00 CLOSE:)(1\aas@@fstack{\prime}44,0\aas@@fstack{\prime}00), and assuming a Tk=Trot=12subscriptùëáùëòsubscriptùëárot12italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start rot POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:12T_{k}=T_{\rm rot}=12 K, we estimate a mass of 0.12‚Å¢(XNH310-8)-10.12superscriptsubscriptùëãsubscriptNH3superscript1081NUMBER:0.12 OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NH POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0.12\left(\frac{X_{\rm NH_{3}}}{10^{-8}}\right)^{-1} M‚äôdirect-productFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\odot}, where XNH3subscriptùëãsubscriptNH3italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NH POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{\rm NH_{3}} is the molecular abundance of NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†with respect to H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} . The total mass for the clumps mapped in our data is ‚àº0.65‚Å¢(XNH310-8)-1similar-toabsent0.65superscriptsubscriptùëãsubscriptNH3superscript1081RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.65 OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NH POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 0.65\left(\frac{X_{\rm NH_{3}}}{10^{-8}}\right)^{-1} M‚äôdirect-productFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\odot}. These values are consistent with those obtained by Reach et al. [Reach et al.¬†1995]. Although we see no sign of current star formation processes, the presence of self-gravitating clumps suggests the possibility of these processes to occur in the future. Therefore, given its proximity to the Sun, this region is an ideal laboratory to study precollapsing physical conditions, preceding new star formation (e.g., Ward-Thompson et al.¬†1994).

On the other hand, the radio-continuum source that lie within our sampled area does not seem to be a young stellar object associated to MBM 12, since it is outside the bounds of the NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†emission. Association with NH33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}¬†emission is a known characteristic of young stellar objects [Anglada et al.¬†1989]. The source VLA B0253+192 is likely to be an extragalactic object.

We thank John Ball, Kevin Dudevoir, and Phil Shute for their help during the observations at Haystack Observatory. JFG and JMT are supported in part by DGICYT grant PB95-0066 and by Junta de Andaluc√≠a (Spain). SP is supported by DGICYT grant PB96-0610.
